fullText: George Orwell’s “1984” returned to the best-seller lists earlier this year on the eve of Donald Trump’s inauguration as president of the United States. But Robert Icke and Duncan MacMillan’s new stage adaptation, first staged in the U.K. in 2013 and opening on Broadway Thursday, remains joltingly timely even without a direct nod to current events.
rejectionReasoning: claude: This appears to be just the opening paragraph or excerpt of a review, providing only contextual setup about the show's timeliness without any evaluation or critical assessment of the production.; openai: The text provided is an incomplete review and does not contain any evaluative content or a verdict on the Broadway production.; gemini: This is just an opening paragraph providing context, not a full review with a clear evaluation of the production.
bwwExcerpt: Even for audiences inclined to feel jaded about revisiting a story from a long-ago school reading list, this '1984' manages to pump new, discomforting life into the mother of all dystopias. Icke and MacMillan also hit on some home truths that feel all too pertinent at a time when so many are called to 'resist' authority. 'The people will not revolt,' O'Brien notes. 'They will not look up from their screens long enough to notice what's really happening.'

keyPhrases.quote: this '1984' manages to pump new, discomforting life into the mother of all dystopias

The tone is enthusiastically supportive with no significant reservations expressed.
